linkTarget.anchoringText: The name of ‘Ghail Formation' comes from the type locality ‘Wadi Ghail' where the formation is approximately 500 m thick (Maurer et al., 2008). The Ghail Formation belongs to the Permian-Triassic Ruus al Jibal Group (RAJ), which overlies the Hagil Formation and is overlain by the Milaha Formation (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Geological map of western Musandam in the Emirate of Ras Al Khaimah,after Maurer et al. (2008) . The black arrow indicates the location of the study section.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological map of western Musandam in the Emirate of Ras Al Khaimah,after Maurer et al. (2008) . The black arrow indicates the location of the study section.

linkTarget.bib:
Maurer et al., (2008)
F. Maurer , R. Rettori and R. Martini
(2008) Triassic stratigraphy, facies and evolution of the Arabian shelf in the northern United Arab Emirates . International Journal of Earth Sciences , 97, 765 784 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Skeletal packstone contains bivalves, gastropods, echinoderms, foraminifera, algae, mollusks and some peloids, which are constituted of fine- to medium-crystalline dolomite. In Figure 2, picture (a) shows an abundancy of bioclasts, which could be gastropods, bivalves and echinoderms. In picture (b), the rounded tubular fragments could be echinoderms or algae. Some small bioclasts are unrecognizable.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Skeletal packstone. The grains observed could be gastropods,bivalves, echinoderms and small peloids, with scale 200 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Skeletal packstone. The grains observed could be gastropods,bivalves, echinoderms and small peloids, with scale 200 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Peloidal packstone has packstone texture, while peloids are the dominant grain types. The grain size is fine to medium. Typically, sorting varies from moderate to poor. Additional grain types include gastropods, bivalve fragments, small benthic foraminifers, echinoderms and small coated grains (Figure 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Peloidal packstone. (a) Big fenestral pores filled with dolomite cement. The rock is composed mainly by peloids, with scale 200 um. (b) Few bioclasts can be observed. It contains peloids of different sizes. Sample is from YG-41, with scale 500 um. (c) Some bioclasts could be bivalves, gastropods and echinoderm, with scale 200 um. (d) It contains lots of peloids, some of which could come from micritization of allochems. Sample is from YG-18, with scale 500 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Peloidal packstone. (a) Big fenestral pores filled with dolomite cement. The rock is composed mainly by peloids, with scale 200 um. (b) Few bioclasts can be observed. It contains peloids of different sizes. Sample is from YG-41, with scale 500 um. (c) Some bioclasts could be bivalves, gastropods and echinoderm, with scale 200 um. (d) It contains lots of peloids, some of which could come from micritization of allochems. Sample is from YG-18, with scale 500 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Big fenestral pores filled with dolomite cement. The rock is composed mainly by peloids, with scale 200 um.
Few bioclasts can be observed. It contains peloids of different sizes. Sample is from YG-41, with scale 500 um.
Some bioclasts could be bivalves, gastropods and echinoderm, with scale 200 um.
It contains lots of peloids, some of which could come from micritization of allochems. Sample is from YG-18, with scale 500 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Packstone-wackestone texture is common in the "transition" zone between massive beds and laminated beds. This lithofacies has texture varying from mud-dominated peloidal packstone to wackstone (Figure 4). Both textures can be observed in different parts of the same thin section. The grain types include small benthic foraminifers, bioclasts including bivalves, gastropods, echinoderms, green algae, coated grains and peloids. In packstone-dominated thin sections, the main grains are peloids and coated grains.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Packstone-wackestone. (a) Photomicrograph showing the presence of big pores possibly formed by dissolution of grains. Scale bar is 500 um. (b) Gastropods and some peloids were observed. Sample is from YG-26, with scale bar 500 um. (c) Big grains could be bivalve fragments or gastropods. Sample is from YG-36, with scale bar 500 um. (d) The grains (indicated by white arrows) could be bivalve fragments. Scale bar 200 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Packstone-wackestone. (a) Photomicrograph showing the presence of big pores possibly formed by dissolution of grains. Scale bar is 500 um. (b) Gastropods and some peloids were observed. Sample is from YG-26, with scale bar 500 um. (c) Big grains could be bivalve fragments or gastropods. Sample is from YG-36, with scale bar 500 um. (d) The grains (indicated by white arrows) could be bivalve fragments. Scale bar 200 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Photomicrograph showing the presence of big pores possibly formed by dissolution of grains. Scale bar is 500 um.
Gastropods and some peloids were observed. Sample is from YG-26, with scale bar 500 um.
Big grains could be bivalve fragments or gastropods. Sample is from YG-36, with scale bar 500 um.
The grains (indicated by white arrows) could be bivalve fragments. Scale bar 200 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of lithology can be observed in the transition zone from massive beds to laminated beds. In thin sections, large grains are observed, like mollusks, gastropods, and echinoderms fragments (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Floatstone. Scale bar is 500 um. (a) Photomicrograph showing the effect of dissolution on the grains later filled with dolomite. In the middle, it could be a mollusk fragment (white arrow). (b) The original grains (indicated by white arrows) could be bivalves or gastropods, crushed by physical compaction and later filled by saddle dolomite.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Floatstone. Scale bar is 500 um. (a) Photomicrograph showing the effect of dissolution on the grains later filled with dolomite. In the middle, it could be a mollusk fragment (white arrow). (b) The original grains (indicated by white arrows) could be bivalves or gastropods, crushed by physical compaction and later filled by saddle dolomite.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Photomicrograph showing the effect of dissolution on the grains later filled with dolomite. In the middle, it could be a mollusk fragment (white arrow).
The original grains (indicated by white arrows) could be bivalves or gastropods, crushed by physical compaction and later filled by saddle dolomite.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Wackestone is mainly formed in laminated beds of Ghail Formation (Figure 6). It is mainly mud supported. Few grains can be observed, including gastropods, bivalve fragments, echinoderms, small benthic foraminifers and pellets.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Photo micrographs showing an example of wackestone. (a) Big grains could be gastropods and echinoderms. Small grains could be peloids or pellets scale bar 100 um. (b) Bivalve fragments were common in the lower and upper part of the sample. In the middle, laminated bed is caused by microbial mats. Scale bar 500 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Photo micrographs showing an example of wackestone. (a) Big grains could be gastropods and echinoderms. Small grains could be peloids or pellets scale bar 100 um. (b) Bivalve fragments were common in the lower and upper part of the sample. In the middle, laminated bed is caused by microbial mats. Scale bar 500 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Big grains could be gastropods and echinoderms. Small grains could be peloids or pellets scale bar 100 um.
Bivalve fragments were common in the lower and upper part of the sample. In the middle, laminated bed is caused by microbial mats. Scale bar 500 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fenestral fabrics are mostly developed in this type of texture and few bioclasts were observed (Figure 7). This kind of texture is mainly observed in the upper part of member B.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Photo micrographs showing an example of mudstone-wackestone textures. The scale bar is 500 um. (a) The pores (white part) are filled by dolomite cement, characterized as fenestral fabric. (b) The bigger pores (white part) could be fenestral fabrics. The grains are difficult to recognize by dolomitization.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Photo micrographs showing an example of mudstone-wackestone textures. The scale bar is 500 um. (a) The pores (white part) are filled by dolomite cement, characterized as fenestral fabric. (b) The bigger pores (white part) could be fenestral fabrics. The grains are difficult to recognize by dolomitization.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The pores (white part) are filled by dolomite cement, characterized as fenestral fabric.
The bigger pores (white part) could be fenestral fabrics. The grains are difficult to recognize by dolomitization.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mudstones are observed in the laminated beds of the Ghail Formation (Figure 8). Fenestral fabrics are very common within this lithology. All the pores are filled by dolomite cement.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Mudstone. The scale bar is 500 um. (a) The fenestral pores are filled by dolomite cement. Matrix is very fine mud or micrite. (b) Irregular fenestrae is present in this sample (white part).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mudstone. The scale bar is 500 um. (a) The fenestral pores are filled by dolomite cement. Matrix is very fine mud or micrite. (b) Irregular fenestrae is present in this sample (white part).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The fenestral pores are filled by dolomite cement. Matrix is very fine mud or micrite.
Irregular fenestrae is present in this sample (white part).

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of dolomite forms in mudstone or mud-wackestone (Figure 9). All the mud matrix was dolomitized. Very few allochems can be identified as ghost texture. Under SEM observation (Figure 10), the crystal shape can be recognized more clearly, containing subhedral to anhedral crystalline dolomite.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Dolomite-rock texture 1: unimodal, very fine crystalline non-planar mosaic dolomite. Scale bar is 100 um. (A) The original texture could be mudstone. The size of crystal is less than 10 um. (B) The original texture could be wakcestone. The size of crystal is around 8 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dolomite-rock texture 1: unimodal, very fine crystalline non-planar mosaic dolomite. Scale bar is 100 um. (A) The original texture could be mudstone. The size of crystal is less than 10 um. (B) The original texture could be wakcestone. The size of crystal is around 8 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be mudstone. The size of crystal is less than 10 um.
The original texture could be wakcestone. The size of crystal is around 8 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of dolomite forms in mudstone or mud-wackestone (Figure 9). All the mud matrix was dolomitized. Very few allochems can be identified as ghost texture. Under SEM observation (Figure 10), the crystal shape can be recognized more clearly, containing subhedral to anhedral crystalline dolomite.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Very fine crystalline dolomite observed under SEM. (C) The mud matrix was replaced by subhedral to anhedral dolomite. The size of crystal is around 10 um. (D) The dolomite crystals are very fine, around 5-10 um. They are tightly packed subhedral to anhedral crystals with no or little intercrystalline porosity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Very fine crystalline dolomite observed under SEM. (C) The mud matrix was replaced by subhedral to anhedral dolomite. The size of crystal is around 10 um. (D) The dolomite crystals are very fine, around 5-10 um. They are tightly packed subhedral to anhedral crystals with no or little intercrystalline porosity.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The mud matrix was replaced by subhedral to anhedral dolomite. The size of crystal is around 10 um.
The dolomite crystals are very fine, around 5-10 um. They are tightly packed subhedral to anhedral crystals with no or little intercrystalline porosity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of texture is more common in member C of the Lofer cycle, where the original texture contains less mud. The average size of this type crystal is 20 um. The crystals are more euhedral, which means the crystals have enough space to grow (Figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Dolomite-rock texture 2: unimodal, very fine- to fine-crystalline planar-e (euhedral) mosaic dolomite. This type is most common in packstone or pack-wackestone. (a) The original texture could be wacke-packstone. All the crystals are tightly packed, with euhedral shape. Crystal size is around 20-30 um. (b) The original texture could be packstone. They are more tightly packed euhedral crystals, with size changing from 10 to 20 um. Scale bar is 40 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dolomite-rock texture 2: unimodal, very fine- to fine-crystalline planar-e (euhedral) mosaic dolomite. This type is most common in packstone or pack-wackestone. (a) The original texture could be wacke-packstone. All the crystals are tightly packed, with euhedral shape. Crystal size is around 20-30 um. (b) The original texture could be packstone. They are more tightly packed euhedral crystals, with size changing from 10 to 20 um. Scale bar is 40 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be wacke-packstone. All the crystals are tightly packed, with euhedral shape. Crystal size is around 20-30 um.
The original texture could be packstone. They are more tightly packed euhedral crystals, with size changing from 10 to 20 um. Scale bar is 40 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of dolomite represents the replacement of matrix. The dolomite crystals are tightly packed, with some crystal-face junctions preserved (Figure 12). The dolomite has more cloudy-cores, which could be caused by non-mimic replacement of allochems, or the presence of inclusions. Most of the original textures are not preserved. Though, some ghosts of allochems can be identified in thin section. It is more common in the massive beds.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Dolomite-rock texture 3: unimodal, fine- to medium-crystalline planar-s (subhedral) mosaic dolomite. Scale bar is 100 um. (A) The original texture could be packstone. Most of the dolomites have cloudy core and clear rim. The crystal size is 50-70 um. (B) The original texture could be wackestone. Some dolomite crystals have cloudy cores, which could be caused by calcite relicts, fluid inclusions or non-carbonate impurities (clays). The sample was tightly packed.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dolomite-rock texture 3: unimodal, fine- to medium-crystalline planar-s (subhedral) mosaic dolomite. Scale bar is 100 um. (A) The original texture could be packstone. Most of the dolomites have cloudy core and clear rim. The crystal size is 50-70 um. (B) The original texture could be wackestone. Some dolomite crystals have cloudy cores, which could be caused by calcite relicts, fluid inclusions or non-carbonate impurities (clays). The sample was tightly packed.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be packstone. Most of the dolomites have cloudy core and clear rim. The crystal size is 50-70 um.

The original texture could be wackestone. Some dolomite crystals have cloudy cores, which could be caused by calcite relicts, fluid inclusions or non-carbonate impurities (clays). The sample was tightly packed.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Medium crystalline dolomite was formed by replacement of grains (Figure 13). The matrix is represented by finer crystalline dolomite. The size of the dolomite crystals replacing the allochems is coarser compared to that in the matrix. Some of the original grains still can be identified, such as gastropods, shell fragments.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Polymodal, medium crystalline dolomites replace allochems. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) The original texture could be pack- to wackestone. All the grains were replaced by dolomite. It could be a gastropod in the middle of the picture. The size of dolomite in the allochems is 60-200 um. (B) The original texture could be skeletal packstone. Lots of grains were observed in the thin section, including gastropods, bivalve fragments, echinoderms, foraminifers, and peloids. The crystal size in allochems is around 60-120 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Polymodal, medium crystalline dolomites replace allochems. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) The original texture could be pack- to wackestone. All the grains were replaced by dolomite. It could be a gastropod in the middle of the picture. The size of dolomite in the allochems is 60-200 um. (B) The original texture could be skeletal packstone. Lots of grains were observed in the thin section, including gastropods, bivalve fragments, echinoderms, foraminifers, and peloids. The crystal size in allochems is around 60-120 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be pack- to wackestone. All the grains were replaced by dolomite. It could be a gastropod in the middle of the picture. The size of dolomite in the allochems is 60-200 um.

The original texture could be skeletal packstone. Lots of grains were observed in the thin section, including gastropods, bivalve fragments, echinoderms, foraminifers, and peloids. The crystal size in allochems is around 60-120 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In thin section observations, this kind of pore-filling dolomite is very common (Figure 14). It is characterized by ‘drusy dolomite', where the crystal size increases from the rim toward the center of voids. Most dolomite crystals are subhedral to anhedral with many crystal-face junctions and straight, compromise boundaries. From the different size of the crystals, it indicates different generations of dolomite cement have occurred.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Dolomite-rock texture 5: medium to coarse crystalline planar-s (subhedral) dolomite cement. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) The original texture could be wackestone. The vug was probably formed by dissolution or burrow, filled by dolomite crystals. Most crystals are clear, which means no replacement of allochems. The size is 100-600 um. (B) They are polymodal, anhedral to subhedral dolomite crystals. Crystal-face junctions were preserved. The crystal size increases from the rim to the center. Crystal size changes from 100 to 600 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dolomite-rock texture 5: medium to coarse crystalline planar-s (subhedral) dolomite cement. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) The original texture could be wackestone. The vug was probably formed by dissolution or burrow, filled by dolomite crystals. Most crystals are clear, which means no replacement of allochems. The size is 100-600 um. (B) They are polymodal, anhedral to subhedral dolomite crystals. Crystal-face junctions were preserved. The crystal size increases from the rim to the center. Crystal size changes from 100 to 600 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be wackestone. The vug was probably formed by dissolution or burrow, filled by dolomite crystals. Most crystals are clear, which means no replacement of allochems. The size is 100-600 um.
They are polymodal, anhedral to subhedral dolomite crystals. Crystal-face junctions were preserved. The crystal size increases from the rim to the center. Crystal size changes from 100 to 600 um.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the samples (Figure 15), the allochems are transformed into fine-grained calcite, and the original internal structures are lost, then calcite has been replaced by dolomite later. Many bioclasts and coated grains are completely micritized to form peloids.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Micritization observed in thin sections. Scale bar is 500 um. (A) The original texture could be peloidal packstone. Dolomite cements fill interparticle pores (indicated by white arrows) or vugs (indicated by black arrows). (B) The original texture could be packstone or floatstone. Many small grains got dissolved and filled by dolomite.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Micritization observed in thin sections. Scale bar is 500 um. (A) The original texture could be peloidal packstone. Dolomite cements fill interparticle pores (indicated by white arrows) or vugs (indicated by black arrows). (B) The original texture could be packstone or floatstone. Many small grains got dissolved and filled by dolomite.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be peloidal packstone. Dolomite cements fill interparticle pores (indicated by white arrows) or vugs (indicated by black arrows).
The original texture could be packstone or floatstone. Many small grains got dissolved and filled by dolomite.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In thin-sections, the dark micrite envelopes surround bioclasts and non-skeletal grains (Figure 16). When the grains are leached away, micrite envelope acts to preserve the shape of the grains during meteoric or early burial alteration. In the samples, all the bioclasts were dissolved to form moldic pores, then filled by dolomite cement later.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Micrite envelope surround grains (indicated by white arrows). (A) The original texture could be peloidal packstone. In the middle, micrite envelope was formed around the rim of the grain. (B) The micrite envelopes were well preserved in this sample. Some were deformed by compaction. (C) Some micrite envelopes were well preserved. In the middle (indicated by white arrow), the original bioclasts could be echinoderm. (D) Small size micrite envelopes were formed at the rim of grains. The scale bar in (A) (B) is 500 um, while in (C) (D) is 200 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Micrite envelope surround grains (indicated by white arrows). (A) The original texture could be peloidal packstone. In the middle, micrite envelope was formed around the rim of the grain. (B) The micrite envelopes were well preserved in this sample. Some were deformed by compaction. (C) Some micrite envelopes were well preserved. In the middle (indicated by white arrow), the original bioclasts could be echinoderm. (D) Small size micrite envelopes were formed at the rim of grains. The scale bar in (A) (B) is 500 um, while in (C) (D) is 200 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be peloidal packstone. In the middle, micrite envelope was formed around the rim of the grain.
The micrite envelopes were well preserved in this sample. Some were deformed by compaction.
Some micrite envelopes were well preserved. In the middle (indicated by white arrow), the original bioclasts could be echinoderm
Small size micrite envelopes were formed at the rim of grains.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Dolomite cements are very common in the study samples from the Ghail Formation; dolomite cements can be found filling vugs (Figure 17). In vugs the crystal size increases from the rim toward the center of voids or interparticle pores in a typical drusy dolomite arrangement.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Different stages of dolomite cement observed in thin sections; (A) under cross-polarized light; (B) under plane-polarized light. Scale bar is 100 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Different stages of dolomite cement observed in thin sections; (A) under cross-polarized light; (B) under plane-polarized light. Scale bar is 100 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: under cross-polarized light
under plane-polarized light

linkTarget.anchoringText: Stylolites and dissolution seams are resulted from chemical compaction, which were observed in thin sections (Figure 18). A stylolite is the most readily identifiable form of chemical dissolution. Stylolites are characterized by relatively high amplitude while solution seams show very low amplitude. The black material in stylolites and solution seams could be composed of varying combinations of iron oxides (Figure 19), bitumen, clay minerals and detrital organic particles.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Stylolites or solution seams (indicated by white arrows) formed by chemical compaction. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) Clay mineral and iron could present along the solution seam. (B) Stylolite was observed between two different kinds of matrix. (C) The solution seam was filled by clay mineral and iron oxides. (D) Stylolite is cutting across dolomite cement, which could be formed at later stage.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stylolites or solution seams (indicated by white arrows) formed by chemical compaction. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) Clay mineral and iron could present along the solution seam. (B) Stylolite was observed between two different kinds of matrix. (C) The solution seam was filled by clay mineral and iron oxides. (D) Stylolite is cutting across dolomite cement, which could be formed at later stage.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Clay mineral and iron could present along the solution seam.
Stylolite was observed between two different kinds of matrix.
The solution seam was filled by clay mineral and iron oxides.
Stylolite is cutting across dolomite cement, which could be formed at later stage.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Stylolites and dissolution seams are resulted from chemical compaction, which were observed in thin sections (Figure 18). A stylolite is the most readily identifiable form of chemical dissolution. Stylolites are characterized by relatively high amplitude while solution seams show very low amplitude. The black material in stylolites and solution seams could be composed of varying combinations of iron oxides (Figure 19), bitumen, clay minerals and detrital organic particles.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Iron oxides and clay minerals present along solution seams. Scale bar is 100 um. (A) Iron oxides are opaque under plane-polarized light. (B) Hematite (red color) and goethite (yellow to brown color) are recognized by reflected light.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Iron oxides and clay minerals present along solution seams. Scale bar is 100 um. (A) Iron oxides are opaque under plane-polarized light. (B) Hematite (red color) and goethite (yellow to brown color) are recognized by reflected light.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Iron oxides are opaque under plane-polarized light
Hematite (red color) and goethite (yellow to brown color) are recognized by reflected light

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Organic matter present along solution seam. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) Solution seam in planepolarized light. (B) The organic matter is recognized by its green color under blue fluorescent light.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Organic matter present along solution seam. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) Solution seam in planepolarized light. (B) The organic matter is recognized by its green color under blue fluorescent light.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Solution seam in planepolarized light
The organic matter is recognized by its green color under blue fluorescent light

linkTarget.anchoringText: Organic matter was observed along solution seam under fluorescence microscopy, which shows a bright green-fluorescent color (Figure 20). In many cases, the black material shows a finely laminated texture with dark translucent brown color in thin section, which suggests a major component of depositional clay. BSE/EDS study also indicate the presence of clay mineral along stylolites (Figure 21 and Figure 22). EDS analysis shows clay minerals rich in Al, Si, K, which could be illite.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: BSE image showing clay along the stylolite in the sample. (B) It is the enlarged area showed in the red square in (A).

formatted-caption.caption-text: BSE image showing clay along the stylolite in the sample. (B) It is the enlarged area showed in the red square in (A).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: It is the enlarged area showed in the red square in (A)
BSE image showing clay along the stylolite in the sample

linkTarget.anchoringText: Organic matter was observed along solution seam under fluorescence microscopy, which shows a bright green-fluorescent color (Figure 20). In many cases, the black material shows a finely laminated texture with dark translucent brown color in thin section, which suggests a major component of depositional clay. BSE/EDS study also indicate the presence of clay mineral along stylolites (Figure 21 and Figure 22). EDS analysis shows clay minerals rich in Al, Si, K, which could be illite.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: EDS mapping of the clay along the stylolites. The clay contains K, Al, and Si, which could be illite.

formatted-caption.caption-text: EDS mapping of the clay along the stylolites. The clay contains K, Al, and Si, which could be illite.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In some samples, it can be observed some intercrystalline porosity formed due to dolomite dissolution (Figure 23).

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Dolomite dissolution at later stage. The dolomite residue can be observed inside of the intercrystalline pores. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) (B) Drusy dolomite filled in vug.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dolomite dissolution at later stage. The dolomite residue can be observed inside of the intercrystalline pores. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) (B) Drusy dolomite filled in vug.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Dolomite dissolution at later stage. The dolomite residue can be observed inside of the intercrystalline pores. Scale bar is 200 um
Drusy dolomite filled in vug

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the samples, bioclasts and peloids have been fractured as a result of compaction (Figure 24). The micritized grains were crushed and then blocky dolomite cements filled the fracture (Figure 24 B).

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Physical compaction of grains (indicated by white arrows). (A) The original texture could be wackestone or packstone. Physical compaction could happen at early stage. Scale bar is 500 um. (B) The grain was micritized at first. Then, it got crushed by physical compaction. The dolomite cement filled in the fracture at later stage. Scale bar is 200 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Physical compaction of grains (indicated by white arrows). (A) The original texture could be wackestone or packstone. Physical compaction could happen at early stage. Scale bar is 500 um. (B) The grain was micritized at first. Then, it got crushed by physical compaction. The dolomite cement filled in the fracture at later stage. Scale bar is 200 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The original texture could be wackestone or packstone. Physical compaction could happen at early stage. Scale bar is 500 um
The grain was micritized at first. Then, it got crushed by physical compaction. The dolomite cement filled in the fracture at later stage. Scale bar is 200 um

linkTarget.anchoringText: In thin sections, two kinds of iron oxides can be observed, hematite and goethite. Under plane-polarized light, the iron oxides are opaque. By illuminating the surface of the sample with a tangential reflected light, red and yellow colored minerals can be observed (Figure 25). According to Tucker (2009), hematite would turn to red color in reflected light while goethite would be yellow to brown color.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Iron oxides observed in thin section. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) The iron oxides are opaque under planepolarized light. (B) Iron oxides changed to red color (hematite) and yellow color (goethite) under reflected light.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Iron oxides observed in thin section. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) The iron oxides are opaque under planepolarized light. (B) Iron oxides changed to red color (hematite) and yellow color (goethite) under reflected light.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The iron oxides are opaque under planepolarized light
Iron oxides changed to red color (hematite) and yellow color (goethite) under reflected light

linkTarget.anchoringText: Also, from the SEM/EDS results (Figure 26), the material could be goethite according to the shape and chemical component. Two different stages of iron oxides formation can be derived from petrographic and SEM observation (Figure 25). One type could be formed in an earlier stage, observed within the matrix. Another one is observed in the fracture, which is cutting across dolomite crystals. It could be formed at later stage. We cannot tell which happens first, hematite or goethite.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Iron oxides observed under SEM. (A) Iron oxides in the middle with rounded shape and needlelike surface. (B) EDS Spectrum of the iron oxides (goethite).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Iron oxides observed under SEM. (A) Iron oxides in the middle with rounded shape and needlelike surface. (B) EDS Spectrum of the iron oxides (goethite).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Iron oxides in the middle with rounded shape and needlelike surface
EDS Spectrum of the iron oxides (goethite)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Calcite cement was observed along fractures, which was identified by Alizarin Red S staining. In the study samples (Figure 27 A), the grains were cut across by fractures. Both calcite cement and iron oxides were observed along fracture (Figure 28). The iron oxides were formed at a later stage.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Calcite cement filled fracture at later stage, which is red color using the Alizarin Red S staining technique. (A) In the middle, the bioclast (gastropod), is cut across by fracture. Scale bar is 200 um. (B) Calcite cement filling fractures and intercrystalline porosity at a later stage. Scale bar is 100 um.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calcite cement filled fracture at later stage, which is red color using the Alizarin Red S staining technique. (A) In the middle, the bioclast (gastropod), is cut across by fracture. Scale bar is 200 um. (B) Calcite cement filling fractures and intercrystalline porosity at a later stage. Scale bar is 100 um.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: In the middle, the bioclast (gastropod), is cut across by fracture. Scale bar is 200 um
Calcite cement filling fractures and intercrystalline porosity at a later stage. Scale bar is 100 um

linkTarget.anchoringText: Calcite cement was observed along fractures, which was identified by Alizarin Red S staining. In the study samples (Figure 27 A), the grains were cut across by fractures. Both calcite cement and iron oxides were observed along fracture (Figure 28). The iron oxides were formed at a later stage.

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: Calcite cement and iron oxides present along fracture. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) Calcite cement fill the fracture, part of which is stained to red. (B) Iron oxides changed to red and yellow color under reflected light.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calcite cement and iron oxides present along fracture. Scale bar is 200 um. (A) Calcite cement fill the fracture, part of which is stained to red. (B) Iron oxides changed to red and yellow color under reflected light.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Calcite cement fill the fracture, part of which is stained to red
Iron oxides changed to red and yellow color under reflected light

linkTarget.anchoringText: Under BSE/EDS study, both calcite cement and organic matter were observed along the fractures (Figure 29). According to BSE results (Figure 29), the grey area should be dolomite, while the white part should be calcite. And the black material could be organic matter.

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: (A) BSE images show calciteand organic matter present along a fracture, adjacent to dolomites.(B) It is the enlarged area showed in the red square in (A). Dol=dolomite; Cal=calcite; Org=organic matter.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) BSE images show calciteand organic matter present along a fracture, adjacent to dolomites.(B) It is the enlarged area showed in the red square in (A). Dol=dolomite; Cal=calcite; Org=organic matter.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: BSE images show calciteand organic matter present along a fracture, adjacent to dolomites
It is the enlarged area showed in the red square in (A). Dol=dolomite; Cal=calcite; Org=organic matter

linkTarget.anchoringText: Stable isotope analyses were conducted on all rock samples collected from the outcrop, in which there were 46 samples performed on bulk rock and 9 samples performed on large dolomite cement. From the results, a cross plot has been generated relating the carbon versus oxygen isotopic signatures of the different types of dolomite (bulk-replacive vs. cements) of the Ghail Formation (Figure 30).

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: Carbon and oxygen isotopic compositions of bulk dolomite and dolomite cement from the Triassic of the Ghail Formation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Carbon and oxygen isotopic compositions of bulk dolomite and dolomite cement from the Triassic of the Ghail Formation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: One representative sample was chosen to conduct the fluid inclusion analysis. All the fluid inclusions observed within the crystals are primary inclusions, in the size range from 1 to 20 μm. Two-phase (liquid and vapour) aqueous fluid inclusions are present in cloudy bands within dolomite crystals (Figure 31). Under UV light observation, the fluid inclusions in the sample are not filled by fluorenscent hydrocarbons (Figure 31 D).

image-wrap.label: Figure 31
image-wrap.caption: Photomicrographs showing the fluid-inclusion (indicated by black arrows) of the Ghail Formation. (A) Planar to sub-planar dolomite cement with dark bends of primary inclusion. (B) Cloudy inclusion-rich growth bands observed in the crystal. (C) Two-phase fluid inclusions were hosted in the bubbles. (D) Dolomite cement and matrix observed UV light.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Photomicrographs showing the fluid-inclusion (indicated by black arrows) of the Ghail Formation. (A) Planar to sub-planar dolomite cement with dark bends of primary inclusion. (B) Cloudy inclusion-rich growth bands observed in the crystal. (C) Two-phase fluid inclusions were hosted in the bubbles. (D) Dolomite cement and matrix observed UV light.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Planar to sub-planar dolomite cement with dark bends of primary inclusion
Cloudy inclusion-rich growth bands observed in the crystal
Two-phase fluid inclusions were hosted in the bubbles
Dolomite cement and matrix observed UV light

linkTarget.anchoringText: Five fluid inclusions assemblages were chosen to measure the homogenization temperature (Th) and salinity (Tm). The range of Th is from 108.8 to 120.3 °C and the average Th is 114.3 °C (Figure 32). The range of salinity is from 14.9 to 18.1% NaCl eq. and the average salinity is 16.7% NaCl eq. (Figure 33).

image-wrap.label: Figure 32
image-wrap.caption: Histogram showing the frequency of Th data of fluid inclusions in the dolomite cement, from Ghail Formation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram showing the frequency of Th data of fluid inclusions in the dolomite cement, from Ghail Formation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Five fluid inclusions assemblages were chosen to measure the homogenization temperature (Th) and salinity (Tm). The range of Th is from 108.8 to 120.3 °C and the average Th is 114.3 °C (Figure 32). The range of salinity is from 14.9 to 18.1% NaCl eq. and the average salinity is 16.7% NaCl eq. (Figure 33).

image-wrap.label: Figure 33
image-wrap.caption: Histogram showing the frequency of salinity data of fluid inclusions in the dolomite cement, from Ghail Formation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram showing the frequency of salinity data of fluid inclusions in the dolomite cement, from Ghail Formation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 34 shows the crossplot fluid inclusion Th and Tm data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 34
image-wrap.caption: Cross plot of homogenization temperatures (Th) vs salinity values of the investigated cements.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross plot of homogenization temperatures (Th) vs salinity values of the investigated cements.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 35 shows data from dolomite samples of the Ghail Formation compared to Permo-Triassic marine carbonates. Note that dolomite cements are significantly lighter than the marine carbonates, indicating a high temperature origin. The bulk dolomites are heavier than the marine carbonates, indicating a low temperature origin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 35
image-wrap.caption: Carbon and oxygen isotopic of bulk dolomite and dolomite cement from the Triassic of the Ghail Formation (this study). The dashed line rectangle represents the range of values for Middle-Upper Triassic carbonates in equilibrium with seawater.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Carbon and oxygen isotopic of bulk dolomite and dolomite cement from the Triassic of the Ghail Formation (this study). The dashed line rectangle represents the range of values for Middle-Upper Triassic carbonates in equilibrium with seawater.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The second approach is to compare dolomites of the Ghail Formation to other dolomites, whose origin has been established by independent parameters. According to Allan and Wiggins (1993), dolomite with δ18O values more negative than −6.5% PDB most probably had a high temperature origin and dolomite with δ18O values more positive than −2.5% PDB most probably had a low temperature origin (Figure 36). This could be considered as a useful guideline for interpreting dolomite origin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 36
image-wrap.caption: A low temperature dolomite field has δ18O values more positive than −2.5% PDB and a high temperature dolomite field has δ18O values more negative than −6.5% PDB. Adopted from Allan and Wiggins (1993).

formatted-caption.caption-text: A low temperature dolomite field has δ18O values more positive than −2.5% PDB and a high temperature dolomite field has δ18O values more negative than −6.5% PDB. Adopted from Allan and Wiggins (1993) .

linkTarget.bib:
Allan and Wiggins, (1993)
J. R. Allan and W. D. Wiggins
(1993) Dolomite reservoirs: geochemical techniques for evaluating origin and distribution . American Association of Petroleum Geologists.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Ghail Formation data have been replotted on high temperature/low temperature dolomite plots in Figure 37. Compared with Fig. 35 and Fig. 37, it shows that both approaches yield the same interpretation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 37
image-wrap.caption: Same carbon and oxygen isotope data shown in Fig. 5.2 for dolomite from Triassic of the Ghail Formation is replotted here on high temperature/low temperature dolomite plot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Same carbon and oxygen isotope data shown in Fig. 5.2 for dolomite from Triassic of the Ghail Formation is replotted here on high temperature/low temperature dolomite plot.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A possible paragenetic sequence for the Ghail Formation is shown in Figure 38.

image-wrap.label: Figure 38
image-wrap.caption: General paragenetic sequence observed from petrographic analysis of the Ghail Formation. The question marks mean we are uncertain about when the diagenetic events happened.

formatted-caption.caption-text: General paragenetic sequence observed from petrographic analysis of the Ghail Formation. The question marks mean we are uncertain about when the diagenetic events happened.
